result.execSummary:
This case has not been concluded. Unless a judgment of conviction is entered, the defendant is presumed innocent of all charges.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

Clerk: Heather.
Case Called: 3:32 p.m. 
State appears by ADA Alex Lech in person. Defendant appears in person, with Atty Jack Mathie.
Date and time set for a motion hearing re: suppress. 
VRCW. 

COURT has reviewed motions.
COURT denies motion to dismiss without a hearing.

COURT has reviewed motion to suppress evidence.
Atty Mathie recites basis for motion.
Atty Mathie stipulates to adjourning this hearing so both parties could have time to review.
COURT to hear arguments today, but will follow up with an oral ruling.
Atty Mathie makes arguments. 
COURT addresses parties.
COURT denies motion in part.
ADA Lech makes arguments. 
COURT addresses parties. 
COURT instructs the State to have a written response filed within 2 weeks from today, Defense has 2 weeks to respond, and then the COURT to have 2 weeks to produce oral ruling.
